reviewText: Very spiritually uplifting.  Takes patience to a whole new level.  For those seeking spirituality, it bring to the forthfront what faith is all about.
Tearjerker with strong moral values stressing commitment, faith and love.  What a joy to see a movie without being embarrassed about language, sexuality or violence.  Highly recommended!

Don't start this movie by selecting the first scene (select Play Movie from the main menu).  There is a large portion of the movie hidden in the introduction (approximately 1/7, I'm guessing).  This movie may have appeared to have more depth had the entire film been seen by me start to finish.  The introduction does provide a bit of character background and begins to build the relationship between Ben and Elizabeth.  That said, the simplicity of the movie allowed me to not get lost when not seeing the first portion of it.

It is "The Notebook" only not as well done as far as the storyline - BUT with morality.  So, if you're hardpressed to find a good Christian film, but don't mind a sub-par story, this one will do - but don't pay full price for it.

If you haven't seen the movie and don't want me to spoil the scenes, don't read further.  I thought the movie was too busy - too many stories, without all of them being fully developed.  My favorite scene was the one where Elizabeth sets the table for the romantic dinner with Will after the return of Ben.  It shows the commitment to her marriage, in spite of her painful loss.  It shows that real life bites you hard sometimes, but if you allow God to take your heart and mold you, He will enable you and it will be a reward in itself.  That said, the movie went more downhill from there for me.  It's a shame, because I think it could have gone the other way.  I didn't feel any emotional connection between the younger Elizabeth and Will and the older Elizabeth and Will.  It's like there are two - or three - different stories told through this film - of different people.  It's too disconnected.  Taking the same actors and applying a lot of make-up and whatever they do to make people look older would have helped a lot, rather than whole new actors that don't really look, feel, or sound like the younger adult characters.  In addition, you don't even get to know their son, so how do you feel the loss of anything to grieve.  There are not even a quick few scenes, perhaps with music playing in the background of their son's birth and the growing up years.  There's no emotional connection to their loss.  If they had done a better job of connecting the stories, this would have been a much better film.  That said, I loved the line where Will says, right before he dies, "Thank you for chosing me."  It points back to the scene where Elizabeth chose not only to stay married to Will, but to love Will and to pour her heart into her marriage, not lamenting what might have been.

The fact that this storyline was so close to the one of The Notebook made me wonder.  The dates of the copyrights of each book are three to four years apart (with The Notebook being published in 1996 and Though None Go With Me published in 2000).  Did Jerry Jenkins come up with the idea to make a "clean" sanitized version of The Notebook?

It may have to do with the fact that I watched this movie in the middle of the night, but I very much disagree with the previous review.  There was a bit of predictablity to this movie, but it was still very sweet and carried a great message.  It speaks the truth that just because you have faith and follow God things will not always be easy, but in the midst of hardship there is comfort and a chance to make a difference.  I found it to be uplifting and enjoyed it.  I even recommended it to others.

This purported to be a faith-based movie.  I don't know, I just watched it because I got it for free and the cable was out.  In short, this is faith-lite if faith at all.  Main character talks about her commitment to God "no matter what" but little else in the movie suppports how she gets through her trials (not backing out of her commitment only?). Then she challenges God for all the rotten things HE did TO her and I personally don't believe God attacks us -- instead I believe He allows things to happen to us.

In any case, much of this story was absurd and implausible.  We are supposed to believe that her father (a strong Christian man) left his daughter homeless and pennyless???  We are supposed to believe in a small, tight-knit town that a young lady (flung to the streets by her father's death and financial irresponsibility) that the ONLY person she could live with was a single lad? In the early 50s?  Please!  Weak story line, marginal acting, silly things like her moving into the house with a guy and her old lady wig were just all too much for me.

This movie, set in the Korean War era, told a very moving story about a young woman and the trials she faced in life after making a contract with God to follow a life of Christian values and teaching. I loved this movie. Starts Cheryl Ladd as Elizabeth Leroy whose faith is tested with each tragedy endured on extraordinary journey. From the book by Jerry B. Jenkins. It's set in 1951 during the Korean War. Elizabeth longs to escape her own small town of Three Rivers to pursue a career. A twist of fate and true love forces her to day. She looses her father who she is real close to. There is also her next door neighbor who is in love with her. She meets the town's new minister who she quickly falls in love with and plan to marry, but he leaves for korea to do God's work. She receives letter that he has died in battle. She is heartbroken. After awhile her neighbor declares his love for her and they eventually marry. After being married for awhile she receives letter from her ex-fiance that he is still alive. She meets him and tells him she is now married. All these events alter Elizabeth life forever and tests not only her faith and inner strength, but her resilience as well. If you loved the Notebook, you'll love this movie.

As I watched this movie, I was surprised and disappointed to see that the lady was never seen praying or confessing her faith with true conviction and  love for God and Christ...(except for a little blessing 15 minutes before the end of the movie).

Therefore, the characters lack of depth and inspiration. This is a depressing movie because little hope and love is proclaimed in Christ.

However real Christianity is how it is portrayed in this movie:
- shallow and passive, distant for a living  and loving God.
Real Christians do not take life's blows one after another with self pity, sadness neither. In the contrary, they put all their hope, love in God and find joy in Christ because if our faith is alive and strong, joy is abundant no matter what life is in a fallen world etc...
God does not test our faith using all infirmities that life brings...this is so wrong to use death, loss and grief as tests from God.

There are a few positive points:
The marriage portrayed, yet superficially, is solid and both characters grow in love for each others, faithful and caring for each others. They share the same faith.

I enjoyed the 50's settings and the decency of these times.
The female character has a beautiful character, despite the shallowness of what defines her faith, she has resilience and enduring courage but does her foundation lay on moving sands or on the firm and solid rock of salvation and faith in Our God and His Son?

it is for each Christians to appreciate and decide for themselves...

I have some VERY SERIOUS misgivings about this movie. However, it can have value if viewed in the proper context and with proper follow-up discussion/critical thinking.

The Christianity portrayed is a VERY watered-down Christianity (Jesus I don't think is even mentioned) - it seems a very "religious" Christianity rather than a "relationship" Christianity - the main character seems to be "committed" to God in a religious sense since she made a commitment to Him and wants to keep that commitment, but she doesn't seem particularly close to Him at all and indeed seems to be very frustrated at Him because of all He has allowed in her life.

Which brings me to my really big beef with this movie:

This movie portrays God as someone distant up there that basically is just out to cause us pain. Through the main character's brushes with several tragedies, lots of questions about God's goodness are raised, but are never resolved in the movie. Basically you can easily come away with a view that God is a God that really doesn't care about our hurts - and almost that he "delights" in causing us pain to "test us" so we will trust Him more. That is NOT the God I know.

There is hurt and death in this world, but God is not out to kill everyone close to me just so He can "test my faith". Who wants to follow a God like that? Not me. And in the movie, you get the clear indication that the main character really doesn't either, but she is just forcing herself to persevere out of duty because of a religious commitment she made early in her life where she decided she wouldn't "turn back" from her decision to follow.

In reality, the deaths and tragic situations in the movie are merely a reflection of life in a fallen world, including our choices. For instance, the death of parents just happens because people do not live forever here - there is a time for us all. Yet, in the movie, the deaths don't come across this way as just something that happens, but rather comes across more that God "has it out" for the main character.

Another tragic situation that occurs centers around a relationship that gets jilted because (slight spoiler) one of the characters (a pastor) believes God is calling him to leave the main character (woman) and go overseas to war - this results in all sorts of hurt and pain and a terrible mix-up that has lifelong consequences. God gets blamed for this too. Yet, as I was watching this unfold, all I could think was it would be far more likely that the guy misheard God and his own choices caused this hurt. It's hard for me to envision God calling this pastor to do such a thing given what we've seen building before that with this woman. Again, it just doesn't mesh with the God I know, and indeed the result of what happens seems to prove that out. If it had really been God, it would have been a whole different outcome because God isn't out just to "do us in" and take away all our joy and any chance at happiness. It seems like the man's choices as a flawed human cause a cascading series of events that hurts all sorts of people (including himself) - and yet, God gets the blame.

And that's the problem. The net result is you walk away from this movie with the following message:

"There is a God. He does what He wants to do. He causes hurt and pain and kills people close to us to test us. We just need to keep persevering and trust Him anyway and do good for others."

Which is really quite depressing and is why I have a very hard time recommending this movie. God is most definitely NOT portrayed as a God of love in this movie and indeed any real relationship with our God of love seems absent.

However, this movie is a very vivid portrayal of a life, with all its twists and turns, and yet a commitment to God remains. And we do see how God works with the events and choices that occur and does still ultimately work things out "for the good" in the main character's life. It's a "case study" of sorts of a life in motion and because this portrayal can be enlightening and cause consideration of how our choices affect others, I do feel there is some value in this movie and it can ultimately be an "uplift" if processed correctly. But I do believe it definitely requires "processing" - it warrants some very strong consideration and follow-up after-the-fact to make sure that you aren't wrongly internalizing the problematic messages stated above.

After you watch this movie, you want to go back and make sure that you go confess how Jesus loves you and is for you, NOT against you! A read of Romans 8 might be in order - even singing "Jesus Loves Me" might help... :)

I strongly suggest that you *NOT* watch this with children of any age or with new-in-the-faith believers. This is a movie more for spiritually-mature adults in the Lord that can appropriately strip out the problematic messages.

The acting and production quality of this film were just fine and the story is interesting and engaging (FYI: you WILL cry in this movie). Think "good made-for-t.v. movie" and that about sums up the quality-level.

Reviewed by Movies For Christians

You might recognize the name Jerry Jenkins from The Left Behind Series.  My wife and I have been fans since before that famous series.  And this movie adapted from Jerry Jenkins' novel by the same name does not disappoint.

It is the story of Elizabeth Leroy, a doctor's daughter, who wants out of a small town.  An associate minister comes to town and she is taken by him.  The story has twists and turns that test Elizabeth's faith severely.  Though None Go With Me's themes include enduring faith, a resilient spirit and love that lasts a lifetime.

I cannot say enough about this film.  Get it, watch it and have some tissues handy.  I don't think you will regret it.

No turning back.) It does seem to diminish her husband's perfectly timed last words, "Thank you... for choosing me."

I thought this was a pretty good movie, although at times rather sombre due to the heartbreak the characters experience. If you like romantic films you will probably enjoy it as love is the main thread in the storyline which is slightly lacking otherwise. The main theme though is that life is not easy even for Christians.  We need to keep following God despite our difficulties and He will help us along the way.  The lyrics from the song, "I Have Decided to Follow Jesus" are quoted as encouragement for Elizabeth, the main character.

This story is also about a woman's love for two men and their love for her.  Her handsome childhood friend Will, has been secretly in love with her, but she thinks of him as just a brotherly type friend.  When the young and handsome pastor arrives and Elizabeth starts to fall in love with him, Will proposes.  However, the love between her and pastor Ben Phillips continues to grow. Their happiness is complicated by the Korean War and Ben's call to the ministry.  Will on the other hand continues to stand by Elizabeth through some very difficult times and tragedies.

Criticisms of the film: Unfortunately the make-up for the characters was very over done which I found distracting.  Also, aging Cheryl Ladd did not come across well on screen.  The older characters in the movie were the age of my parents and I thought they were trying to make her look way too old.  Instead they should have hired a different actress to play the part of the aging Elizabeth and had Ms. Ladd continue to play her as a middle aged woman as she did in the film as well.  Also, I was puzzled about the ring she took off being too big for her...again that was distracting. I don't know how close this is to the book as I've never read it and I've heard conflicting reports.

The two men in the film present a different type of support to Elizabeth.  My preference is for Will whose love is completely unconditional and he stands by her no matter what happens.  Ben is an encouragement to her in terms of her faith and what God is calling both of them to do.  The romantic scenes are very touching and rather heartbreaking at the same time.  Both men want only what's best for Elizabeth and truly love her which makes for a complicated love triangle!  The acting, particularly by David Noroña and Brad Rowe, was excellent and both are believable suitors for Elizabeth.

I'd recommend this film as I think it has a good message and it emphasizes the things that are important in life, but it does contain some imperfections that you need to overlook to fully enjoy it.  However, the idea of holding onto your faith through all the trials in life is a very good message.

Love this movie.  It is a moving story, of joy and pain.
It is refreshing to see a movie that is filled with raw emotion, but not violence, foul language or smut.
I would HIGHLY recommend this movie

I came across this film by accident. It was one of those nights flipping through channels and thinking "Nope, nope, ugh, ugh" until I hit the Christian network for my area. I don't even know why I set the remote down. But this movie came on and I watched it start to finish.

I wish I would have had a box of Kleenex beside. I never cried so hard, so many times in my life. Perhaps because some of the events in this movie were identical to my own life. I don't know but, I absolutely loved the movie.

There's no room for the skeptical, cynical, over-analytical audience here.

In the end, the movie reminds us that no matter how bad these days can get, to hold fast to our hope, our faith, our what ever you call it. Don't give up. Because, the ending might be the best part of all, and it's worth sticking around for.

It's a reminder that all things work together for the good of those who love Him.

I am planning to buy a few copies to share with others so they might be blessed also.

I cried a lot and truly felt for Elizabeth. This movie is very encouraging at the same time. As a christian I know that I won't neccesarily escape hardships and great loss, I sometimes fear this. This movie encouraged me not to fear, but trust Him. I'm really confused by the person who thought the author just wanted to make a clean version of the Notebook, they are not that similar. This movie if similar to any other I would say a clean version of Pearl Harbor. I mean in the Notebook Noah and Rachel McAdam's character still end up getting married and the only similarity is the time period and an alztimers spouse. In Pearl Harbor the leading lady believes her love to be killed in the war and marries someone else before finding out that he survived, but even then there were different circumstances behind that. All this to say that this movie was not so similar to the Notebook that I could see how anyone would think he wrote it to be a clean version of the Notebook. When I read that on another review it made me wonder how long ago the person watched The Notebook!

There was one swear word at the beginning of the movie--thus, garbage can material.  The rest of the movie was ho-hum--unless you want to get a glimpse of how people dressed in the 50s.  As I said, I threw it in the garbage can.  I cannot have people think that I, as a Christian, condone obscenities since in Ephesians 5 we are told to abstain from all profanity.

Though the budget may not have been all that large and some of the wigs are bad, this is a great film.  The story line is a bittersweet feel good story.  I have watched it at least four times over the past several years.

Be sure you have your Kleenex in hand when you begin this movie. A story filled with heart and lots of realism, gets you involved instantly in the life of the main character. A storyline that intertwines a cast of characters you will grow to love right from the start. No bad language, violence or sexual scenes. If you are looking for a family film... this one fits the bill!
This was a nice movie.  I agree that it was a little predictable.  It's a good clean family movie with a lesson to be taken from the story.
I enjoyed this movie, though I would not call it realistic.  You could guess the story line early, but it has some good characters and sparks the emotions.

I love this movie because you don't see this story to much anymore.. It is a true life love story and you will not be disapointed with the role Cheryl Ladd plays.
the movie arrived to me in excellent condition and quick shipping. I would recomend this seller to everyone, service is excellent.

This is an excellent movie, I highly recommend this movie as it contains such a powerful message, especially for those who have experienced a 'loss of a love one'.
Thanks for the prompt service and speedy shipping.

Excellent movie.  There are so many movies out there that I don't want to watch or to let my grand daughters watch!  This is a movie that is Christian oriented and consistently holds to very good values and morals.  I would not hesitate to recommend this movie to anyone that enjoys movies that don't make you cringe.
The is really a good Christian, family movie.  I highly recommended to all who love to watch clean, family, Christian value movie.

I ENJOYED THIS MOVIE. IT PROVES THAT A PERSON CAN GO THROUGH THE STRUGGLES AND STILL HANG TO JESUS. I WAS SO ENCOURAGED AND OVERJOYED! THIS LADY LOST EVERYTHING LIKE JOB BUT SHE HELD ONTO  HER INTEGRITY. THAT IS ALWAYS INSPIRING! MANY ARE THE AFFLICTIONS OF THE RIGHTEOUS BUT THE LORD  DELIVERETH US OUT OF THEM ALL. I WAS GLAD TO SEE AN AUTHOR WRITE THE TRUTH ABOUT FAITH AND THAT IT MAY FLUCTUATE DEPENDING ON THE SITUATION BUT IT DOESNT DIE. THIS LADY WENT THROUGH THE FIRE AND CAME OUT AS PURE GOLD. IT LETS US KNOW WE CAN DO IT.. BUT NOT ALONE. WITH JESUS ONLY. HE SAID WITHOUT ME, YE CAN DO NOTHING. FIVE STARS IN MY BOOK.. WONDERFULLY WRITTEN AND PRESENTED! A REFRESHING FILM!:)

I love reading Mr. Jenkins books. The same title above in print is a beautiful book, that I couldn't put down.
I cried and cried reading the book. I love the book. However this movie like all the other movies I've seen
that were taken from the writing of Jenkins, is just horrible. And this movie plummets into the hell
of horribleness. This movie has nothing to do with the book, except for title and a few names, with a familiar
scene thrown in every now and then.
The books main focus was God, the movies main focus is some willy nilly ideas thought up by some left winger.
I thought I would enjoy this movie, but it was terrible.
The plot was terrible, the acting was terrible, the message was terrible, the whole thing was just one terrible
mess.
If you loved reading the book, don't buy the movie, it will just make you sad that such a wonderful book could
be made into such a loathsome movie.
Please Mr. Jenkins, don't sell your copyright anymore, unless you have absolute control over what is being produced.
My wife and i (male) loved this movie very well done recommend to any struggling with Christian life
This is a beautiful story about a young girls life. It is about a choice she made and how it affected her life. Very well done , a family movie.

This is a good movie that, although it is a bit of a "Chick Flick", has a good life message for both sexes and all ages. Nothing in it should embarrass any age group, and the story floating over the message has interest. Life is not about the fireworks, fireworks are nice but fleeting. Life is about the journey and the character built over the years, which, without patience and perserverence cannot be built.

I was very pleased with the packaging and time of arrival. This DVD had a few
light scratches,however it was described as having no scratches. Other than that I am satisfied.

Hi :)  I purchased this movie from wholesaledvdsforless.  I received it just a few days after i ordered it!  The box and the dvd were in excellent shape!  Would definitely order from this company again!  Great job! :)

What a beautiful display of relationships maintained through God's unfailing & enduring love...(there were one or two things that i don't believe was displayed His way, however, all in all it really is a great movie and well worth watching and the money spent on it.) :)
I did not care for this movie. I thought it was quite depressing and sad. I watched it alone to preview for my kids and I did not even show it to them.

A must see movie for every family. Trials and hardships shape our character. Cheryl Ladd does an outstanding job in this movie. It details how young people should take time to listen and learn from the wisdom of the elders in their family. The movie shows us when you make a commitment to God, stand by it. Life will be guided and it will make a difference in other's lives.Though None Go with Me
This movie made me cry and laugh and it really gave me a point of view I'd never thought through before.  Great movie!

This was a movie the entire family enjoyed watching together - no sex, violence or swearing. Good message for everyone about not giving up even when everything seems to be falling apart all around you. I was hoping for another outcome in the movie but this was more like real life which made it still good because it wasn't all fairytales. My two young children also sat through the entire movie glued to the screen. Will watch many more times.
This is one of my absolute favorite movies. I ordered it from this company and it iwas delivered to me in about two weeks in brand new condition. I was very pleased with my purchase.

Someone needs to mention that this story is about death. Every time she turns around - the one she loves - dies. It is a very depressing movie. She has one death after another to deal with. Yes, she keeps her faith with God. That does not take away from the fact that she has a very hard life to live because of all the death that follows her.

A truly realistic Christian movie about a 'real' Christian....A beautiful love story about three people who know how to love in the spirit....The grandaughter is almost a double of Reese Weathersppon...
So very few films are about commitment to something higher than one's own abmition or pleasure....A true treasure...
To anyone who loves this film may I suggest A Man Called Peter..my very favorite Christian movie...
THIS WAS ONE OF THE BEST MOVIES CHERYL LADD HAS DONE IN A LONG TIME. THE BIBLICAL RESPONSE TO THE NOTEBOOK.

This film is to be commended for its message: no matter what God brings into our lives, we are to faithfully follow him and trust His sovereignty.  The main character had her faith tested many times and she always chose to do right.

A secondary theme is faithfulness and fidelity in marriage.  This is in complete contradiction to modern Hollywood sensibilities about "love".  Very powerful message.

From a conservative Evangelical Christian viewpoint, however, the content of faith (salvation is in Christ alone) is absent--just the general non-offensive sense of God.  Christianity, according to the film, is not about the gospel and making disciples, but about social causes.  Furthermore, the faith and morals of the main characters were not passed on to their child and grandchild, who is in rebellion and running off (and presumably living with) a man who is not her husband.  This is disappointing, but all too frequent in second, third, and fourth generation Christianity.

From a cinematic standpoint, the acting isn't always the greatest and the granddaughter's interest and then lack of interest in her grandmother's tale doesn't seem realistic.

Again, the message is extremely powerful--well worth the time.
I had seen this movie on television and just had to have a copy for my personal files because it so inspiring about following God's will.

I THOUGHT THIS MOVIE WAS BETTER THAN THE NOTEBOOK. I LOVED IT. THE MESSAGE WAS THAT GOD ALLOWS THINGS TO HAPPEN IN OUR LIVES TO HELP US UNDERSTAND AND HELP OTHERS GOING THROUGH HARD TIMES COMES THROUGH VERY CLEAR. I CRIED THROUGH ALOT OF IT, AND FOUND IT VERY ENTERTAINING.
Very well done. Inspiring, uplifiting, wonderful. The only problem is that there is no closed captioning or subtitles which makes it difficult for the hard of hearing.

Powerful!  Moving!  Heartfelt entertainment!

The story of a young woman with plans and dreams of her own, who yields her life to God, and in doing so instead trusts in His plan for her life.  Through trials and tribulations, hardships and heartaches, her faith, though questioned and tested at times, endures and upholds her, shaping not only her own life, but of those around her.

It's a story about life and love, faith and friendship, hope and humanity.  A movie that takes you through the whole gamut of the human experience.  Full of meaning and memorable moments, the strength of the story is such that it stays with you long after the closing credits.

Encouraging, edifying, and uplifting.  This is a story that speaks to the heart, strengthens the spirit, and nourishes the soul.

Guaranteed to make you cry.

Highly recommended for all!

I usually enjoy most romance movies, even ones most would consider sappy.  However, this has to be the first romance movie--based on a book--that had me absolutely bored to tears.  I kept thinking it would end any second, and then it just kept going, and going, and going.  I think if it had ended earlier, it might not have been so bad.

Also, when the grandmother was trying to get her granddaughter to stay, the story she told didn't seem to have any relation to the granddaughter's situation.  So, I don't know why she was telling it...

It was a very depressing movie.  One that sort of says, "All God gives us is destruction, but keep on going anyway..."  I don't think God's like that.  He may give us strength to continue on despite circumstances, but He doesn't make bad things happen in our life.

I think perhaps the book might have been better (I've never read it).  If you haven't read the book, don't watch the movie.
Thanks for the fast service.  What a touching movie.  Brought back a LOT of memories.

I saw this movie twice this week-end on the Hallmark Channel.  It was a great movie.  This movie is about Love, Faith and your trust in God.  I recommend that you purchase this movie.  I am so glad to find that is on DVD.  Trust me you do not have to see this first before you purchase.  Excellent, Storyline and Acting.

I really enjoyed the story line of this movie. I haven't read the book...so I wasn't dissappointed in them changing the story line. Sometimes that is a plus. I was sorry to see a swear word in it...which I felt was totally uncalled for in the movie and just didn't fit. I just add that for those who prefer to buy movies without them. My mom even loved this movie...has watched it about five times. THis is a really good movie with a nice story. Enjoy!!

First class job!  Cheryl Ladd as usual is wonderful and is in perfect form.  Many may not recognise her at times because of the aging special effects. All the actors/actresses did a superb job. Well done.  Good story.  Great ending.  I highly recommend it!
This is one of the best movie i have seen thus far. I recommend this to all, family, friends, ladies church group. I really gets inspired and lifted up when i watch this movie. Bravo.

There are no villains in this movie.  There are two nice men who are interested in the same wonderful woman.  It is true to life.  It is inspirational.  It is an excellent movie.  I recommend it to all persons and all ages.

I took a chance with this movie, not knowing what to expect, and I was very pleasantly surprised at how wonderful it was! Such a touching and moving story ... I have to admit the acting was not the best (excluding Cheryl Ladd of course who's always wonderful), but actually, the script is so good it really didn't seem to matter ! Highly recommended for everyone !
I have watched this movie several times and cry my way through it each time. What a great story. I will probably watch it several more times.
I thought the acting was BAD; no one was believable.  But, despite that, the story line was very moving. I will be thinking about the message for a long time to come.

Written by acclaimed author Jerry Jenkins, I would highly recommend this movie. It's one of my favorite movies of all time and focuses on God and the importance of faith, even when it's difficult to maintain that faith.

Though None go With Me is a heartwarming family movie that focuses on what's important. It's well written and the actors and actresses did an excellent job. It is a touching movie that opens up discussion on God's plan for our lives and Jeremiah 29:11, grief, importance of sharing stories with younger generations, love, and selflessness.

We travel through the life of Elizabeth Leroy, who grows up in the 1950s in small town America. Through some triumphs, some heartbreaks, and some hardships, we watch as Elizabeth continues to follow and serve God.  By telling her story, can she persuade her wayward granddaughter that all she endured was worth it?

Part romance, part drama, there is nothing objectionable in this movie and I would recommend it for ages tween to adult.

I have added this movie to my Mom-Approved movie listings on my Wordpress blog.

I read the novel this film is based on years ago and I've never forgotten it. The movie stayed true to the novel's themes and is a wonderful, uplifting story that refutes the idea that bad things never happen to Christians. But it also shows how God can carry us through when tragedy happens and even use our lives as an example and an encouragement to others. Very moving and memorable, and a movie I wouldn't be ashamed to recommend to family and friends of any age.

Having read the book, the movie was predictably disappointing, and I am surprised that Jerry Jenkins would allow them to stray so far from the original story.  In addition, the book was based, very realistically in Three Rivers, Michigan...a small town of about 7800, where I've resided for more than sixty years. Of course, the movie doesn't mention the state (not that I heard anyway), and I suppose that was omitted to increase appeal for the general public. In any case, it definitely wasn't filmed here, and as a long time resident, I found that part sadly lacking. However, had I not read the book first, nor had any knowledge that the story was based in Three Rivers, Michigan, I would have given it five stars. It's a beautiful story, well done and well acted, heartwarming and uplifting, and illustrates perfectly, the inner peace and security derived through  a true walk with God.

This movie is excellent for families.  It has the emotions of loved ones going off to war, and the ones left behind to go on with their lives. All the cast are very well suited for their parts and the movie is a refreshing change for what is on TV.
"Though None Go with Me" is a thought-provoking, entertaining movie.
A very touching stpry that addresses several issues of life such as death, faith, alzheimers, unfaithfulness in marriagand more
Fabulous movie for everyone
The movie case was broken so the disc was just sliding around inside the case
Love this movie! If you haven't read the book...it's a must read as well! This is a romantic movie, that touches your heart. Clean movie-which is rare to find now a days.
very good book
It was a good movie. Was sad a couple times. But in the end I cried with joy. I will keep this one always

I read the book quite a while back, so I can't say how closely the movie follows it, but the movie was very good.  Persevere through trials and always trust in God.  Pretty good message no matter what and no matter how hard.

A very good movie love Cheryl Ladd
I also wanted to praise the speedy delivery I received my order sooner than I expected.

I was excited to watch the dvd because the book was excellent, but beyond sad...a real tearjerker.  While some things followed along the lines of the book, the movie just didn't do it justice.  Wrong era, they way Will cared for her & his family, the story of their 3 children (in the movie only one), the way she took care of Will, none of that was portrayed in the movie.  I encourage you to read the book.
